The third file (atcoder_ABC170_A) reads a line of space-separated numbers. It counts how many numbers there are until it hits a 0, then outputs that count.

int power(int base, int exp) {

    int result =1;

    for (int j=0; j<exp; j++) {

        result *= base;

    }

    return result;

#include <math.h>

So in C code:

#include <stdio.h>

#include <math.h>

int main() {

    int N;

    scanf("%d", &N);

    int count =0;

    int temp = N;

    while (temp>0) {

        temp /=10;

        count++;

    }

    int ans =0;

    for (int i=1; i<=count; i++) {

        if (i == count) {

            if (i%2 ==1) {

                ans += (N - (int)pow(10, i-1) +1);

            }

        } else {

            if (i ==1) {

                ans +=9;

            } else if (i%2 ==1) {

                ans += ( (int)pow(10,i) - (int)pow(10, i-1) );

            }

        }

    }

    // Now, convert ans to a string.

    char ans_str[20]; // enough for big numbers.

    sprintf(ans_str, "%d", ans);

    // Now process through second program's logic.

    // Second program's processing:

    char *s = ans_str;

    int length = strlen(s);

    char ch = 0;

    for (int i = length-1; i >=0; i--) {

        if (s[i] != ' ' && s[i] != '?') {

            ch = s[i];

            break;

        }

    }

    ch = tolower(ch);

    int is_vowel = 0;

    if (ch == 'a' || ch == 'e' || ch == 'i' || ch == 'o' || ch == 'u' || ch == 'y') {

        is_vowel =1;

    }

    // The second program's output is "YES" or "NO".

    char second_output[5];

    if (is_vowel) {

        strcpy(second_output, "YES");

    } else {

        strcpy(second_output, "NO");

    }

    // Now process through third program's logic.

    // The third program's input is the second's output (a string like "YES" or "NO").

    // The third program reads a line, splits into numbers, counts until 0.

    // So the input is the second_output string.

    // So the input array is the second_output string split by spaces.

    // But the second_output is either "YES" or "NO", so the array is [ "YES" ] or [ "NO" ].

    // So the third program's processing:

    char *input_str = second_output;

    char *token = strtok(input_str, " ");

    int result =0;

    while (token != NULL) {

        result +=1;

        if (strcmp(token, "0") ==0) {

            break;

        }

        token = strtok(NULL, " ");

    }

    // Output the result.

    printf("%d\n", result);

    return 0;

}
